The gameplay is like a rainbow that has been crushed into crysaline form and mainlined through your eyeballs, it is fast paced and frantic couch coop in it purinst sense. I often throw this game up on a big projecter and it always draws crowds. People will scream when the horns start getting close to the enemy hearts and the camera zooms in for a slow motion shot.\nThis game is absolutely amazing when ti works. This game is good, however there my be unfixable bugs of which I found.

Some include:

Teleporting out of the ring if pausing just before hitting the ground at a high velocity.
Being stuck in the ground with your horn, unable to move until someone barges you out.
The AI just forget what they're doing and stop moving completely.

Apart from that, this game is pretty good, and the bugs can possibly be fixed (I'm not to sure), and the AI were an amazing feature which the creators added, as now I can practice my skills (Of which I have many) for when I go against my foes.

On the subject of AI, I have found that it is very good at this game, and take a fair amount of skill to take down. This can seem a little annoying for people who just started to play the game, but really, just learn to play the game (I have never understood this problem which people have with learning curves).

I would recommend this game, as it is only £6.99 at the time of writing this, so is quite cheap for a game which can be a different experience for each person you fight, as everyone brings new skills to this game.

I thoroughly recommend StarWhal, the old free version. Avoid this one unless they fix it.

I can't recommend this game.

This is one of the least playable party game I've had to play. The game works fine, let's be clear on that. Everything runs smooth. It's just that you can't get from A to B in a controllable manner (unless it's a short straight line you don't really need to precisely follow).

So this is a physics-based chaos handling game that doesn't really handle it well. You will laugh and shout with you friends playing this game because it's funny how you cannot do anything as you initially intended to. If it's your thing, please consider buying this game.

If you don't mind playing solo, AND if you take the clumsiness of the controls as a hardcore challenge of its own, please throw all your time in mastering the controls and beating the challenge levels.

Starwhal: Just the Tip is the most fun you've ever had piloting a narwhal in space. Hands down. It's still early acccess so I hope it just keeps getting better and better!

It definitely needs online multiplayer, but it could also use abilities like a booster pack or horn extender or the ability to pierce through enemy narwhals for a short duration. Something to liven up and add more diversity to the play-style.

Also we could use a mode where score is dependent upon kills and deaths, either +1/-1 like Smash or +2/-1 like All-Stars and for normal score mode an ability to make it a timed match with no point-limit would be great.

As is, this game is worth every penny, so get busy Starwhaling or get busy dying.

Quickie review: The best multiplayer game I've played to date.

Explaining the game to someone to play it is a long shot, but when they realise just how satisfying skerweing a friend's cyberspace narwhal is, there's no going back. Even for people who don't care for games at all, Starwhal seems to be an exception. The simple controls are easy to grasp, and before you know it, you'll be screaming and swearing at your former human allies.

After playing the demo for countelss hours with flatmates, the Steam release with multiple levels, game modes and customisation of narwhals  has only added to the experience. Along with the vibrant and poppy graphics and fab soundtrack, even at the moment this game is well worth the asking price.

So yeah, it's pretty great. I'm eagerly anticipating the new game modes, they should be stellar too

One of my favorite newer competitive Indie games, regardless of the fact that it's still currently a part of Early Access. I'm yet to play with more than 3 people, but I look forward to playing full games with 4 users. Controls are a little tough to get used to at first, but the learning curve is the same for most people and knowing that your struggles with your Narwhal are the same as the person next to you eases the curve a bit. I wasn't expecting the games to get as tense and competitive as they did, but it escalated quickly. A fair amount of the game modes I have no interest in outside of the main timed and multi-live combat sessions, but those themselves are worth it if you have a regular group of people to play with. A great party game for friends who want something a little different that isn't altogether unfamiliar territory. If the developers are looking at this, the only suggestion I have is to make this online multiplayer, so I can experience this with friends who I don't live near.
